Award.AbstractNarration:
Doctoral Dissertation Research: Academic Performance, Gender, and Hiring

Research consistently shows that differences in levels of education--e.g., a high school diploma
versus a Bachelor's degree--are associated with different labor market outcomes, including earnings and occupational prestige. Scholars do not yet understand whether differences in academic performance among those with Bachelor's degrees also contribute to employment inequalities. This question is an important consideration not only because achievement is stratified within the student population, but also because students differ in the extent to which they invest time and effort in their academic performance. Women, in particular, typically have higher grades and spend more time on academic activities than men, but it is unclear whether these efforts pay off at the point of hiring. Accordingly, this project addresses three key questions: Are there returns to academic performance in the labor market? If so, what are they? And, do these returns vary for men and women? This research can help us understand persistent inequalities between women and men.

The research will conduct original, experimental data collected in two related studies to answer these questions. Study 1 is an online audit experiment, also known as a field experiment or correspondence study. Matched pairs of job applications will be sent to approximately 1,250 entry-level employers in five metropolitan areas in the U.S. Applicants' college GPA, gender, and major will be experimentally manipulated to establish their causal effects on several labor market outcomes, including callback rate and potential starting salary. Study 2 is an online survey experiment designed to analyze the mechanisms behind the patterns observed in Study 1. A pool of respondents who are hiring decision-makers at U.S. firms will evaluate the same resumes presented in Study 1 and provide feedback about applicants and their credentials. Taken together, these studies will help explain how and why employers evaluate academic performance for men and women, while potentially uncovering important inequalities in the transition from college to work. This research contributes to sociological research on persistent inequalities as well as has practical implications for human resource and other managers interested in promoting diversity and workplace fairness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I conducted an online audit study and an online survey experiment designed to examine the effects of gender and college academic performance in the entry-level labor market. The audit study demonstrates that achievement has very different effects on men’s and women’s employment outcomes. While men have approximately the same outcomes regardless of their achievement—such that men with a “C+” average are called back at about the same rate as their “A” average counterparts—women have the best outcomes when they have moderate achievement. Moderate-achieving women are called back more often than those with low achievement, but this advantage does not extend to high-achieving women. In fact, high-achieving men are called back significantly more often than high-achieving women—at a rate of about 2:1.

The penalty for high-achieving women, however, is most concentrated among those who major in a particular field of study. Although high-achieving women business and English majors are not penalized relative to their men counterparts, high-achieving women math majors are penalized. These women receive approximately one-third as many callbacks as similarly situated men. This general patterns holds even when the sample is limited to jobs in the financial and information sectors—perhaps the most relevant industries for students who major in quantitative disciplines. Because women are most readily penalized when they major in math, a field that has historically been male-dominated, my findings suggest that employers are most resistant to women who are high-achieving in fields where they are under-represented and assigned low expectations for performance.

I also conducted an online survey experiment with a sample of hiring decision-makers to clarify the causal mechanisms related to my findings. The closed-ended portion of the survey shows that employers tend to reward very different traits when they are evaluating men’s and women’s resumes. Men who are perceived as competent and committed to their jobs are more likely to receive a callback, implying that men are rewarded for signaling traits that are traditionally thought of as necessary for job success. Women, however, are more likely to receive a callback when they are perceived as likeable—in other words, when employers intuit (based only on the woman’s resume) that the woman is good-natured, sincere, pleasant, trustworthy, warm, aware of other people’s feelings, and lacks aggression. The open-ended portion of the survey reiterates these findings, and shows that moderate-achieving women, more than any other type of applicant, are routinely perceived as likeable and socially skilled. Thus, moderate-achieving women are often considered ideal candidates for entry-level positions because they are expected to make the workplace enjoyable and do not pose a social threat to existing employees.
